I was having a difficult time understanding how to work with imaginary numbers but I found a few tricks that help a lot and I wanted to share here.

When you multiply any 2d complex number you can legit just add the angles of the two numbers relative to the positive real axis going counter clockwise. (5+5i)² is 50i because 45⁰+45⁰=90⁰. This trick works for non-complex numbers too but its less impressive there. I imagine there's probably a similar trick in higher dimensions

The thing that got me comfortable with even higher dimensional multiplication is remembering that every time you multiply you can look at it as finding the area of a rectangle.

Imagine you have a rectangle with one side being 2+4i+3j+9k and another side being 3+2i+0j+3k. Section off each intersection of numbers and draw smaller rectangles in a chart like pattern.

Just remember the way figuring out the positive/negative and the i/j/k value of each rectangle works by using the chart or by following the circle going clockwise in the order i, j, k. i times j equals k, and j times i equals negative k and so one in a circle (going counter clockwise like that second example makes the sign flip).

(Clockwise examples with negatives -i × j = -k, -i × -j = k) (counter clockwise examples with negatives -j × i = k, -j × -i = -k)

The bottom row on up for the example I gave you would have

2(3+2i+0j+3k) or 6+4i+0j+6k

4i(3+2i+0j+3k) or 12i + -8 + 0 + -12j

3j(3+2i+0j+3k) or 9j + -6k + 0 + 9i

9k(3+2i+0j+3k) or 27k + 18j + 0 + -27

You get your final result by adding all the rectangles together.

6+4i+6k+12i-8-12j+9j-6k+9i+27k+18j-27

Rearranging to

(6-8-27) + (4i+12i+9i) + (-12j+9j+18j) + (6k-6k+27k)

-29 + 25i + 15j + 27k is the resulting quaternion when you multiply the example quaternions i gave you.

You can do this for as many dimensions as you want, all you have to do is remember to look up the relevant table.

I know I could have just used a calculator online or foil and follow the chart and I kind of did, but that representation of each number as sides on a rectangle really helped me understand how to do this process.

Its really empowering to know I can multiply any dimensional number with any other number by hand.

Stereographic Projections are not just a fun way to visualize quaternions, they represent the proper way to set up the algebra. Angles, sin and cos are actually very complex, unnatural, and problematic by comparison. The rational parametrization of the unit circle [(1-t^2)/(1+t^2),2t/(1+t^2)] or the unit sphere [2r/(1+r^2+s^2), 2s/(1+r^2+s^2), (1 - r^2 - s^2)/(1+r^2+s^2)] is key here.

Also I think viewing Quaternions as "4D vectors" is actually not that helpful: the vector part indicates the axis of rotation while the scalar part indicates the AMOUNT of rotation, this is much easier to describe in terms of the equation for the circle I gave above than with angles; NJ Wildberger has coined the term "half-slope" to refer to this alternative way to view rotations. Thus, the first parameter of the quaternion is not some imaginary 4th dimension, but a simple algebraic way of encoding rotation around an axis which is given by the the other 3 coordinates.

→Positive
i j k i
Negative←

same sign ij, jk and ki are positive k, i and j
same sign ik, ji and kj are negative j, k and i
different sign ij, jk and ki are negative k, i and j
different sign ik, ji and kj are positive j, k and i

All lectures on quarternions are given by mathematicians, via complex numbers. Maybe the following practical application will motivate the need.

Rotations in 3D can be expressed in terms of two angles, theta and phi. One of them lies in the plane formed by two of the orthogonal axes, say X and Y; and the other in the plane involving the third axis, say X and Z. Any 3D rotation can be expressed as sine and cosine of theta and phi.

So, what is the problem? Why are the quarternions useful? Trigonometric functions such as sine are computed as infinite series. (Look up Taylor Expansion for the Sine and Cosine functions). Exact solution involves infinitely many terms. Bit real time gaming demands fast computation. Yet, truncation of a series as approximation necessarily involves errors. So what is one to do?

This is where quarternions come in; they involve only dot and cross products of real numbers — very fast and at the same time exact and precise.

Basic Geometric Algebra (Clifford/Grassman), where you actually calculate an "i" is a lot more understandable than trying to understand Quaternions, etc.  A 3D multivector has 2^n parts, with 1 scalar, 3 vector, 3 anti-vector, and one antiscalar part -- (1,3,3,1) ... binomial theorem determines the pattern.  Quaternions are MISSING the vector and anti-scalar part!  A multivector is a combination of all axes turned on/off, hence 2^n components.  Everything is a result of the basis vectors (e_1, e_2, e3) being self-cancel (e_n e_n = 1) and anti-commuting (e_n e_m = -1).  A bivector (aka anti-vector) squaring to -1 is a consequence.  With only that, just distributing across all the parts of a multi-vector generates all of n-dimensional Euclidean geometry.  Geometric Algebra really really clarifies geometry; particularly where things like determinants, cross-products, and "dot-products" (which are slightly wrong in the standard notation) just fall out as trivially discoverable consequences.  It eliminates the handedness distinctions.  It is non-commutative in places where it corresponds with high-dimensional rotations, which means it behaves like real geometr, etc.

Why are radians and degrees still used to describe angles, as in this video? It is so much simpler to use whole rotation units of measurement, in which 1 represents a rotation of 360°, 1/2 represents 180°, etc. Then the irrational (and transcendental) value pi (or 2*pi) disappears from many calculations. Also, rotations by 360° naturally can look like rotations of 0° (simply by requiring the units to be integers).


Similarly, quadrant rotation units, in which 1 represents a rotation of 90°, also eliminate pi, and make trigonometry much simpler. If, additionally, the ternary (base-3) number system is used with quadrant units, trigonometry becomes easier, since, for example, the sign of the sine function depends on the quadrant only, not on the fractional part of the ternary quadrant unit of measurement.


One of these two units of angular measurement is probably best, but this depends on our starting to use them and seeing which does the best job of making physics calculations simpler and more natural.

Still hate quaternions, but by pausing a lot between not understanding huge chunks of words flying by at me and thinking about it a lot, this helps me with a couple of my qualms. I think the way its written has been causing a lot of confusion, because it makes it look like it's "real math", when the reality is that it's just as much "real math" as concatenating strings. Yes there are similarities, but really it's just doing its own thing, and that's why the order matters, just like if you "added" strings in another order it wouldn't come out the same. What I'm seeing right now is that it's not really a formula, so much as a set of operations. A (and then do) B (and then do) C (and then do) D. It would make more sense to me as 4 lines of code, rather than a bunch of letters and numbers pretending to be ordinary math, when it's more like an algorithm or multiple function/method calls in a particular order.

(Disclaimer after writing this up: Just thinking out loud and trying to piece it together here, but this is making more sense than it ever did before, for me.)

So it's doing one thing after another, representing a number of relative moves/translations/changes, not simply an absolute position. You could think of the end result after all changes are done as an absolute position, the way you can think of a string after concatenation in terms of its final result, eg:

"You" + " can " + " do" + " it" = "You can do it"

But this isn't ordinary addition, it's really saying add these letters on to the end of the other string, it's not "true addition" even though it is really "adding on" in a certain sense. You can think of the overall thing as an "absolute string" (if that makes sense), being the final result after all "additions"/concatenations, but in reality it's a set of operations/changes that affect it relatively based on where or what it is currently at each step. So changing the order of things changes the recipe so you get different results, just like if you changed the order of string concatenation: " it" + " can " + " do" + "You" = " it can doYou"

In other words, it's a series of relative changes to its position, which won't come out the same if you treat it like an x,y,z absolute position or rotation where you can modify individual parts independently, because in that case each part of the x,y,z is a statement in its own right about how far in that direction something IS, like individual traits, even though you would also be fine treating it as 3 different moves too in that case.

In other other words, "right 5, then up 2" is the same as "up 2, then right 5", which is the same as the result and absolute position of "5,2". Quaternions just don't work that way.

The nice thing is that if we only care about rotations, we don't have to get into this 4th dimension nonsense and it seems to ends up being closer to what I thought rotations always were or were supposed to be in the first place, when I couldn't understand how gimbal lock would be a problem. I always asked how it could be, until I realized people are moving the axes separate from each other instead of altogether, which might be all you can do for certain things in the physical world, but makes no sense if it's all digital, and doesn't necessarily have to be that way for everything in real life. I imagine instead of rings that only rotate the rings inside them, you have a sphere with 3 little motors touching, where each one moves it along one x/y/z axis. That way they don't get all weird and overlapping, they just rotate the thing a certain amount on a set axis, the way moving on a coordinate plane just moves the thing on the one axis.

I'm still a bit hazy if that's exactly what quaternions are doing (without the scalar, in a unit sphere), or if it's just similar. Or if I'm just getting confused altogether because quaternions are distilled evil. The more I think about it, the more I start feeling it has to be the last one.

Every unit vector is a square root of -1, and there exists a unique (modulo sign) unit vector û for every quaternion q s.t. q = a + bû with a, b ∈ ℝ. Quaternions not only are useful in quantum theory, but also in general relativity, describing four-vectors. It is better to see this if one describes quaternions as paravectors in 3-dimensional space.

Let V be a vector space and F be the scalar field under V. Let P be the direct sum of F and V, such that if p is in P, s is in F, and v is in V, then p = s + v. Now define an inner product on V such that v•v = ||v||^2, and v•w = 0 if w is orthogonal to v. In other words, the inner product is Cartesian. Then the multiplication operator of P is defined by p*q = s.t + s(v) + t(w) + v•w, where p, q are paravectors, s,t are scalar elements, and v,w are vector elements, with * being the paravector multiplication operator, and . denoting the multiplication of scalar elements in F. Define the magnitude operator by ||p||^2 = p’*p with v’ = -v and s’ = s being the conjugation operator, such that p’ = s - v if p = s + v. Then p’*p = s^2 - v•v =
||p||^2. One has v = x(i) + y(j) + z(k), where i, j, and k are unit vectors in V, and x, y, and z are elements of F.

Now it is evident that the algebra of P is equivalent to the algebra of H, the set of quaternions. Further, we can define division too. Given some p, p^(-) = p’/||p||^2, where ^(-) denotes the multiplicative inverse, or otherwise, the denominator operator, if one wishes to call it this. Then for some v in V, v^(-) = - v/(v•v). This is still equivalent to quaternions division.

In relativity, the 4-position is a parevector of the form (ct, r), with r = x(i) + y(j) + z(k), as a function of proper time τ, and ct being the time coordinate multiplied by the speed of light. The spacetime element, which is usually described as the square of the Lorentz invariant magnitude of the 4-position, is equal to the quaternions square (or paravector square) of the 4-position with itself. Namely, ||X||^2 = (c.t)^2 - ||r||^2.

In this respect, four-vectors, which are a special type of paravectors, can also be treated as quaternions.

The 3Blue1Brown channel on YouTube is chock full of brilliant visualizations and discussions of mathematical and scientific ideas. But I question whether it’s all that useful to explain quaternions via spherical projection into lower dimensional, and hence more “intuitive” spaces. Perhaps it’s a useful visualization if you already know something about quaternions. But as an “intro to rotation via quaternions” there might be a much more intuitive approach, which I’ll supply below.

I should mention, as the video alludes to, that this discussion only applies to unit quaternions, the subset of quaternions whose norm is one, the subset of quaternions which correspond to 3-D rotation. [The norm of a quaternion is the “distance” of a quaternion to the origin: sqrt(w²+x²+y²+z²) given the quaternion w+xi+yj+zk.]

When you work with quaternions for any period of time in practical graphics applications where they appear (such as the popular Unity gaming/simulation development environment), you quickly discover that it’s best not to peek too much “under the hood” to examine the actual quaternion coefficient values: w, x, y and z. There are two alternate representations of unit quaternions, one three dimensional, and the other four dimensional, which are far more intuitive.

The older approach is to describe an arbitrary rotation in three dimensions via Euler angles, a series of three rotations, usually first around the x-axis, then y-axis, then z-axis, thus resulting in a 3-element tuple, usually (α, β, γ), or (φ, θ, ψ) represented in radians or degrees. Each set of Euler angles translates to an equivalent unit quaternion. Each unit quaternion can be represented by a particular triplet of Euler angles with the angles specified within some periodic range (usually –π to π or 0 to 2π).

Euler angles have their disadvantages in that the underlying computations are relatively inefficient and can be inaccurate on computer system. In particular, you have to watch out for gimbal lock when applying successive rotations with the rotation state described via Euler angles.[2] When you represent the rotation state via quaternions in successive rotations, you don’t encounter either of these problems.

An alternate way to visualize a unit quaternion is to specify an arbitrary axis of rotation, represented by a unit vector v⃗, and a scalar angle θ specifying how much rotation occurs around that axis. The tuple (θ,v⃗) is four dimensional: the three real coordinates describing v⃗, and the fourth value from the angle θ. For any unit quaternion w+xi+yj+zk, with sqrt(w²+x²+y²+z²)=1, there is an equivalent tuple (θ,v⃗) and vice-versa.

To a certain degree, this alternate representation of quaternions is analogous to Cartesian versus polar coordinate systems in 2-D space. The cartesian and polar representations of conic sections such as circles and ellipses have roughly equal complexity. But as you represent other curves in space, it’s often the case that a polar representation will be easier to express than a Cartesian one (or vice versa). By my way of thinking about it, this (θ,v⃗) alternative “polar” representation of quaternions may be simpler to understand, in the sense of being more intuitive than the raw representation of quaternions which is by definition Cartesian in nature (with four mutually orthogonal axes).

You can intuitively visualize this polar representation of rotation by sticking your right hand in the air with the thumb pointing along the axis of rotation v⃗, and the fingers curling to indicate the angle θ. Four dimensions represented by use of one hand! [Use your right hand to represent left-side application of rotation using quaternions, use your left hand to represent equivalent right-side application of quaternion rotations.]

Unlike Euler angles, you don’t end up with gimbal lock problems if you apply several rotations in a chain, though it still ends up being more efficient (though less intuitive) to work purely within the realm of quaternions on computer systems. The Unity package displays quaternions via nine values, actually: three translation values along the x,y and z axes, three scaling values along the same axes, and the three Euler angles around the same three axes. But this doesn’t suggest a nine-dimensional space, per se, since a (non-unit) quaternion can describe all three operations simultaneously using just four real coefficients.

The video below describes the alternate (θ,v⃗) representation quite nicely, though it delves into the specifics of OpenGL and a “QT” software packages in a course relating to computer graphics using these specific software tools.[1] Interestingly, although the presenter makes numerous mathematic and factual errors in the presentation, such as referring to the originator of quaternions as Heisenberg, not Hamilton, the concepts presented are quite spot on. The presenter shows the tuples in a slightly different form, {cos θ, (sin θ) v⃗}, but this is a representational detail not worth going into. It’s fairly straightforward to derive (or find online) the formulas to convert between unit quaternions and Euler angles, or unit quaternions and the (θ,v⃗) or {cos θ, (sin θ) v⃗} representations.

They are the same here. They are both the distance from origin and provide a the measure of magnitude/"size" of a number (which is a gives number or 0).
It's always a case of magnitude = z = sqrt( a² + b² + c² + d² +...)
In 1D, we only have a so it's z = sqrt(a²) so we just take away the sign, and they don't tell the formula, for simplicity.
In 2D, z = sqrt(a² + b²) usually called the Pythagorean Theorem. For example, if you walk 10', turn 90°, walk 10', you have walked 20' but only moved sqrt(10'² + 10'²) ≈ 14.142' from your start.
In 3D, z = sqrt(a² + b² + c²) gives the distance from the floor in one corner of a room to the opposite corner on the ceiling (assuming everything is at right angles). To "walk" along each edge you could have 10' + 10' + 10' = 30', but the distance is really only ≈17.32'

When left multiplying the quaternion q, the circle perpendicular to the 1->q circle is rotated by acos(real(q)).
This means that if you then right multiply the result with the complement every point point originally on the 1->q circle is back where they started. Because the distance the 1->q circle rotates depends on the real part and the imaginary part sets the direction.

But the perpendicular circle gets rotated further in the same direction as during the first multiply until you end up with a rotation around the vector part that is twice acos(real(q)).
And that is why the half angle is used when constructing quaternions from angle-axis.

The best, practical explanation of a unit quaternion used to describe a change in orientation (from a reference point or previous orientation) that I've come across is even simpler. The vector component (i, j, k) describes the axis of rotation in 3D space (x, y, z), and the real component is the cos(half the angle of rotation). A zero rotation is (1,0,0,0). A +90* rotation around the x axis is ~ (0.707, 0.707, 0, 0). A 180* rotation around the y axis is (0, 0, 1, 0). In this frame work, a positive rotation around an axis is identical to a negative rotation around the negative of the axis. So (a, b, c, d) = (-a, -b, -c, -d). A conjugate is reversing only the direction of rotation even though it's expressed by inverting the axis or rotation. (a, b, c, d)* = (a, -b, -c, -d) but this is equivalent to (-a, b, c, d).

To help you visualise a hypersphere. Think of the sphere you see in Blue's video. Now remember that this sphere is actually not 3 dimensional, since the sphere is projected in your 2 dimensional screen. Now how could you visualise an extra dimension on that sphere? Easy, just look at your computer's screen from an angle, and imagine a sphere sitting on top of Blue's sphere in the video. Now combine the 2D sphere and your 3D sphere into one object in your imagination and you have a closer representation of a hypersphere. You are still seeing a 3D sphere, but if you can consider the sphere in Blue's video to be 3 dimensional, then your combined sphere should be 4 dimensional ;)

A way that you can train yourself into doing so, is to start with a hypercube. Here is an example: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0_-v3xv7_FM
